question.text: A large proportion of oxygen is left unused in the human blood even after its uptake by the body tissues. What is the fate of this O<sub>2</sub>?

options.text: It raises the <math><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></msub></math> of blood to 75 mm of Hg.
It is enough to keep oxyhaemoglobin.
It helps in releasing more <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> to the epithelial tissues.
It acts as a reserve during muscular exercises.

solution.text: Tissue are able to utilize only 25% of <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> carried by arterial blood. The venous blood is still 75% saturated with <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>. This <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> acts as a reserve during muscular exercise.
